bibl.author: Glass
bibl.note: This document, dated November 25, 1806, is a letter to the U.S. Agent to the Cherokees, Colonel Return J. Meigs, from Cherokee headmen The Glass, Dick Justice, (Lurkill?) at home, John Lowrey, John Bogs, Porch Flower, Cumberland, and Tuskeheke gathered at Glass' house on Lookout Mountain in the Cherokee Nation. They request that ferry transport conducted by John Riley and Robert King be stopped because the Cherokees of the upper towns are determined to prevent the construction of a proposed road from Georgia to Cumberland by way of Lookout Mountain.

div1.p: you Remember at our Consell at Sautey we Spoke to you Respecting John Riley ferey that him and Robart king for to agree you Recamend to us to git pay for fereys what is the reson that Robber king will Cross travelers by forse you will Consedder the Bennefit of the Cherokees and Stop Robart kings flat Landing if there is aney Bennefit to be got we out to have it of our one Land
div1.closer:
I am with Respect frends and Brothers
N B Sryou Rememer that the uniteed State applyd for arode from gorgi to the Cuberland by the way of the Loukout montain our peopel of the upper town is now in Consel at ustenarey is deturmed to Stop the Rode if it is trew what we have heard after ther Consel is over you will hear it from them if it is trew that they talk of Dowing it we Dont belive they Can do it after being give up in publick Consell
